conclusion: The object starts from rest, so its velocity at any time t equals the time-integral (area) of the acceleration–time graph from 0 to t.
As long as the acceleration is positive, the instantaneous velocity keeps increasing; once the acceleration becomes negative, the velocity starts to decrease.
The velocity reaches its greatest value exactly when the acceleration changes sign from positive to negative (i.e. when a = 0 for the first time after t = 0).
a = +2 m s⁻² from t = 0 s to t = 1 s (horizontal segment).
a decreases linearly from +2 m s⁻² at t = 1 s to −2 m s⁻² at t = 3 s (slanted segment).
a crosses the zero line halfway between t = 1 s and t = 3 s.
Linear drop: a(t) = 2 − 2(t − 1) for 1 s ≤ t ≤ 3 s.
The object’s velocity is maximal at t = 2 s.
